dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sun spikes through the jostling leaves of a maple tree. A strong wind bends them back, showing their light green bellies. This is a modest house in a row of modest houses. Propane tanks and farmland at their backs show this neighborhood be more rural than suburb. CURTIS LAFORCHE(35) stands in his driveway. His eyes, loc on the sky, narrow as he stares at... A STORM CELL stretching out on the horizon in front of hi It's a bruised sky filled with a vicious mixture of black gray clouds. They swirl in and out of one another sending wispy tentacles toward the ground. Curtis stands, awestruck. The clouds move fast overhead. He looks up as they overta his position. A light rain begins. The rain pats the ground. It makes soft indentions on his cotton shirt. He watches it hit the concrete, falling har now. He notices something strange. The rain makes dark spots on the sidewalk. He pulls his shirt out and sees dark spots forming there. He holds his palm out flat in front of him. The rain pools. He rubs the water through his thumb and fingers. It's an amber color, viscous, like fresh motor oil. Curtis looks to the sky, the rain pelting his face now. Jagged, angry clouds blanketing overhead. The wind bends back the trunk of the maple tree. Curtis stands alone at the base of the surging STORM CELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis holds his head under the running shower nozzle. Co clean water rushes over his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAMANTHA(29) stands at the stovetop stirring eggs in a pa She's still dressed in her sleeping attire, an oversized shirt and pajama bottoms with cartoon frogs on them. HANNAH(5) sits at the kitchen table tearing up a piece of toast and feeding it to the dog. 2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah is a blonde little girl with a large hearing aid wrapped over her right ear. It clips into her hair near t back of her head. The dog's name is Red, a Rhodesian Ridgeback that appreciates the attention. Curtis enters the kitchen and kisses Hannah on the head. the same motion, he takes the piece of toast from her han and sets it on her plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes a seat) No, no, no...Don't feed the dog darlin'. Hannah immediately picks the piece of toast back up and f it to the dog. Samantha brings the pan over and spoons eg out on everyone's plates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks babe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You slept late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I need to go. What you got going today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to finish up some curtains for Saturday, and Nat and Cam are coming over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Cammie said she just needed to get out of the house. Samantha takes her seat at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell Nat to take it easy on her. Curtis gets up and goes to Hannah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cam can hold her own. We need to send in the deposit for the beach condo. He kneels beside his daughter's chair and waits for her t make eye contact. She looks over at him. He speaks using sign language. Three broad, slow gestures. 3.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you. Hannah puts her arms around his neck and he squeezes her. stands and grabs a sack lunch off the counter. On his way out, he kisses Samantha on top of the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just write the check, babe. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Bye. Samantha sips her coffee as Hannah feeds more toast to th dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she signs) No more food. You, eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis shoulders his way out the front screen door. Keys his mouth and sack lunch in his hand, he makes his way do the porch steps and onto the front walk. He pops open the chain-link gate and heads for the PICK-U parked on the street. Clear blue sky overhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Small soybean plants slouch in the noonday sun. A slight breeze picks up, jostling the leaves, but the sound is drowned out by a loud, mechanical rumbling. A spiral drill churns up dark soil as it digs deeper into ground. Curtis, wearing work goggles, grabs hold of the drill's cabling system and yanks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, let's keep going with that bit! It'll go another 10 feet! He yells to DEWART(36), a big guy sitting at the controls a diesel powered WELL-DRILLING RIG. The truck has a long rusted bed with metal scaffolding raised HIGH on its back

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We won't get the gravel pack down today!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?! 4.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those clouds! We're gonna have to call it! Curtis looks back to a potential STORM. Gray clouds formi across the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy hour starts at five Dewart!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if it's rainin'...Ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samantha sits at a table running a long piece of sheer fa through her sewing machine. She's making curtains. NAT(37) sips a screwdriver from a clear plastic cup desig not to sweat. She's a woman with rough edges. CAMMIE(24) cradles a brown-haired BABY on top of her pregnant, eight month belly. As Nat speaks, she looks out a sliding glass door at her kids, DJ(7) and SUE(5), playing with Hannah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were just drinkin' and laughin' and oh, my god...it was like I was bein' in a museum and I saw the progress from apes to men. I saw it. I saw the future. Dewart, that was him...that was going to be him in 20 years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god. Cammie laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me tell you, you laugh. You laugh. But this little one in your arms is gonna be shufflin' in a bar just like `em. Yep...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah! Samantha jumps up from her sewing to see outside. Hannah, with her back to the house, bangs a 2 X 4 with a rusted n in the end into the ground. Samantha is out the door. 5.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samantha walks briskly, talking to the other children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Samantha takes a wide line around Hannah, who continues banging the two-by-four into the ground. As soon as the child sees her mother, she stops. Samantha crouches in front of Hannah, gently taking the b away from her. Samantha signs with her hand and speaks at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Don't touch. Hannah tilts her head, looking off to the side. Samantha touches her chin bringing her eyes back around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (signing and speaking) You understand? Hannah nods once, "yes".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oksy. Come here. Samantha stands and takes the board to a trash pile in th back corner of the yard. A STORM SHELTER is buried in the ground just behind the pile. It's a grass covered mound w two rusted metal doors angled toward the sky. She throws the board onto the heap and wipes her hands on pants. Staring at the pile, she lets out an irritated sig Thunder rumbles low in the distance. She looks up at the approaching clouds and calls to the children as she walks back inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, DJ. Bring the girls inside.

dialogues.speaker: THUNDER STRIKE.
dialogues.text: The drill bit spins as rain pelts the ground turning the soil into black mud. 6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis holds a rain slicker over his head. He watches as hole they are drilling fills up with brown water. He lift his boot, which makes a sucking sound as it dislodges fro the mud. Looking at the horizon, he sees no sign of the storm lett up. He looks to Dewart, who smiles at him from behind the controls of the rig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? It's not my fault! I told you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. All right...All right! I'm callin' it! Shut it down! Dewart gladly eases back on the lever at his knee.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. LAFORCHE HOME
dialogues.text: Samantha holds the front door open as Nat and Cammie leav with their children packed up and in tow. It's raining pretty hard outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye guys. Thanks for coming over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call next week about the Lions Club supper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye Cam. Running for her car holding a jacket covered car seat. Samantha closes the door and listens to her quiet house. rain outside is the only noise. She heads to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE KITCHEN,
dialogues.text: Hannah is sitting Indian-style at the glass doors watchin the rain. Samantha walks over and kneels down behind her. She wraps her arms around Hannah, who lifts a hand to the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you sign s-t-o-r-m? 7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samantha puts her hand onto the glass next to Hannah's an signs "s-t-o-r-m". Hannah turns to see her mother's face, and Samantha uses both hands to make the signed symbol. Fingers, spread and bent, moved downward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Storm. Hannah looks back out the window. They watch the storm together.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. CURTIS' TRUCK/DEWART'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: The blue top of a small cooler is knocked to the floorboa as Dewart fishes the last Busch tallboy out of icy water. cracks it open and takes an extended sip. Curtis, sitting behind the wheel of his truck, looks at h drunk friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta get home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nat and me been lookin' into a threesome. We've been chattin' with a girl online from Canton. Yeah. Big `ol girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's big?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's about two fifty, two seventy five. She can't be no taller than 5 foot. Dewart starts laughing, which makes Curtis laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit man. The laughing subsides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see me and Sam gettin' into somethin' like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I don't guess you would. Dewart is staring at Curtis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a good life Curtis. 8.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm serious. I think that's the best compliment you can give a man, take a look at his life and say, that's good. That guy's doin' somethin' right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. It ain't always so easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell I know that. Dewart sees something out his window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah shit. I gotta go...Manana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night. Nat, in a house robe and slippers, weaves her way through maze of junk on their front lawn. Dewart passes her without saying a word. Curtis watches a she follows him inside the house, still talking. He shift into drive and pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights are out and the house is quiet. Curtis eases o the front door and steps inside. Standing on the door mat he slips off his mud-caked boots and gently sets them asi

dialogues.speaker: AT HANNAH'S BEDROOM DOOR,
dialogues.text: Curtis places his palm flat on the door and lets it open. Hannah is curled up with the covers. He watches her sleep Samantha, barefoot and wearing a sleep shirt, walks up be Curtis. He turns his head when she approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey baby. She wraps her arms around his waist and he lifts his elbo make room for her. They whisper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She do all right today? 9.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was fine. She's still not playin' with the others, though. She can't connect. Honey, you gotta clean up that trash pile in the back. She fished out a board that had nails on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get to it this weekend. It's quiet for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still take off my boots so I won't wake her up. She smiles up at her husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still whisper. He pulls her tight. They stand together in the doorway. T house is silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis loads pieces from the trash pile into a wheelbarro He keeps an eye on Hannah as she jumps on a small, plasti playscape in the middle of the backyard. The dog, Red, paces by the back door. He's agitated, but movement is limited by the length of rope tied from his collar to a nearby post. He barks. THUNDER STRIKES. Curtis flinches at the loud boom. He looks to the sky and sees dark clouds twisting overhead. Hannah plays, unaffec by the noise. To get a better view, Curtis moves from beneath a tree in corner of the yard and surveys the large swath of farmlan that runs up to his property. Chain-link fencing partitions the yard from a deep concre culvert that leads out to the open field. A giant STORM CELL gathers force on the horizon there. Red barks incessantly. He winces and strains against the rope tied to his collar. Curtis flinches again as A BOLT OF LIGHTNING streaks to t ground in the distance. Sparks shoot into the air leaving circle of scorched crops. Another CRACK of thunder. 10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A light rain begins. Red snaps his head around and bucks into the air. He gnashes at the rope. Curtis collects Hannah off the playscape and turns back t the approaching STORM CELL. He holds up his hand and stud the falling rain. It's the thick, amber colored liquid. With Hannah in his arms, Curtis watches, awestruck, as wi tentacles drip to the ground forming a collection of THRE TORNADOS out in the field. Behind them, Red's teeth fray the rope at his collar. He thrashes his head, the rope SNAPS, and the dog flies towa Curtis and Hannah. Curtis turns to see Red charging them. He barely has time set Hannah down before Red catches him by the forearm. They crash to the ground, tangled together. Rain coming d hard now. Curtis yells and waves Hannah back. Red, snapping, buries his teeth into the muscles in Curtis' arm. Blood streams from the wound. Curtis screams in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis bolts up in bed grabbing his forearm. He grinds hi teeth and doubles over in pain. It takes a moment for him find his bearings. His breathing slows. He gently rubs his hand over the ski on his arm. Sweat has collected around his collar and temples. From the bed, sheets in a twisted mess, he looks around t room unsure of what just happened to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eggs cool on a plate. Curtis sits at the kitchen table dressed for work. He sta vacantly at his breakfast. He looks up at Hannah. She sits on the floor surrounded b toy building blocks and plays with the dog. She rubs unde Red's chest and in turn he licks her face. She smiles and gently pushes him away. Samantha sits with her knees up drinking coffee. 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear me? You got to be home, showered, ready to walk out the door by six tonight. Curtis stands up and goes over to Hannah. He grabs her of the floor and she begins to protest with kicks and crying

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. I just want her to eat her breakfast and stop playin' with the damn dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's fine down there. She had toast already. Curtis, against flailing, manages to get Hannah in her ch Curtis backs off, frustrated. Hannah climbs down from her chair and goes back to the floor and the dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah. Come here. Hannah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? He stops and checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't eat anything? Heading out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay. Curtis is gone. Samantha looks at Hannah on the floor wit the dog. 12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The main headquarters of Delta Agri-Pro is housed in a gi metal building. A row of cheaply built, 70's style office with drop tile ceilings line the left of a large warehous that contains all manner of agricultural and construction equipment. Tractors, backhoes, welding rigs, etc. A GROUP OF MEN, many of which were represented at Gator's yesterday, sit in folding chairs or stand in a semi-circl around JIM THOMPSON(53). He speaks, clipboard in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say you had control over the weather Russell, what I did say was that the top shelf has to be cleared by the 15th. That's non- negotiable. Dewart eats from a bag of Sunflower seeds. Curtis stares down at his forearm. He rubs the skin there. Jim runs a finger down his clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Umm, Curtis. Where we at on that east 82nd site? Curtis snaps his head up, takes a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yesterday slowed us down. We couldn't get the second pilot hole drilled. Jim drops his head and the clipboard falls to his side. A melodramatic move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It rained for two hours yesterday. Two hours and our entire schedule went in the toilet. We lose the permit if you're not out of there by end of day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: End of day Curtis. Curtis nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Valerie tells me that the father son pancake cook off... 13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis and Dewart walk to Curtis' truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I gotta make a stop before we head out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think we got time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. There's time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dewart stands by a flatbed cart with a prefab DOGHOUSE sitting on it. Curtis loads chain-link fencing materials onto the cart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wheels of the well-drilling rig are half sunk into th muddy soil. Curtis stands over the hole being drilled. The turning me pole suddenly seizes up and stops. Smoke begins to seep u from the hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonofabitch. Dewart jumps down from the control panel to take a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We stripped that bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Well, bring it up. We gotta re-set it. Dewart walks back to his controls. Curtis heads to the ca of the drilling rig and checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. Something catches his eye in the distance. Clearing past rig, he walks out into the adjacent field. He removes his goggles, eyes fixed on the acres of farmla that stretch for miles in front of him. In the sky overhead, 14.

dialogues.speaker: AN ENORMOUS FLOCK OF BIRDS ROLL IN UNISON.
dialogues.text: Hundreds of them make up a black swarm that twists and sh in the air. They dive bomb then ascend in intricate, GEOMETRIC patterns. Curtis watches, mesmerized. Dewart strains a wrench against a bolt as the drill scree in reverse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis! Curtis acknowledges Dewart but can't take his eyes off th pattern of birds. They shrink and stretch from thick clum to long cylindrical tubes. A choreography. Curtis reluctantly heads back to the rig, which is shriek with the SOUND of metal on metal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever see birds fly like that?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding his hand to his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?! Curtis looks back, giving the birds a final review.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. CURTIS' TRUCK/HOUSE
dialogues.text: The sun has just set adding a purple hue to the sky. Curt steers his truck up to the front curb of his house.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH HIS WINDSHIELD,
dialogues.text: He sees Samantha standing by her car, the back door open. She watches him pull up. Hannah is already packed into he car seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: PARKED,
dialogues.text: Curtis climbs out and walks to the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on we gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Jesus. I could really use a shower. 15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samantha isn't having it. She climbs in the passenger sea Curtis makes his way to her car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis' work boots are encased in dry mud. Chunks have broken off and pepper the thin blue industrial carpet. Hi mud-stained fingers tap on the top of a desk. Dirt caked under his nails.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: So if you continue with the basic vocabulary, this will allow you to communicate with your children better. Curtis sits, filthy, at a school desk he doesn't quite fi into. A TEACHER speaks to a ROOM FULL of PARENTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Between the ages of four and seven the focus is more on the sign and then later we'll begin adding the alphabet as more of a support syster. Now in ASL... Curtis looks over at Samantha, who is sitting in the desk next to him. She won't look at him. He cranes his neck around to see toward the back of the r An ASSISTANT TEACHER sits on a large, colorful rug with a GROUP of CHILDREN, all different ages, playing games that teach hand signs. Hannah actively participates in the gro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the male sign is signed at the forehead area. For example, father is signed up here like this...Father, very good. Curtis turns back in his chair and makes the sign for "da along with the other parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis, Samantha, and Hannah sit on the floor in a circle atop the colored rug. Samantha turns over large flashcards with illustrated sce on them. They take turns making the corresponding sign. Curtis stares at Samantha, but she's still giving him the cold shoulder. Finally, while holding up a card, she look at him. He signs, "I'm sorry". A fist moving in a circula motion at his chest. 16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am sorry. She looks to Hannah and signs, "swim".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you stink. You smell really bad. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I smell good. She smiles, begrudgingly, and then signs to Hannah, "Dad" "stink". Curtis turns to some ladies behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I smell good? Samantha laughs and tries to cover his mouth with her han

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See. Maybe I should marry her instead. They continue to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis slams the door to his truck, sealing him off from torrential rainfall outside. He shakes water off, wipes his face. The windows are smea by thick, dark rain. It's hard to see out. He looks over to Hannah sitting in her car seat. It looks odd on the front bench of the truck. He signs to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (signing and speaking) You okay? She nods. He cranks the truck and turns on the wipers. Th liquid on the windshield streaks into long smudges. Curti leans forward to get a better view of the street. He chec his blind spot and pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop lights blur into hazy red and green spheres. Curtis checks the rearview, but the back window is covere the rain. He tries rolling down his window, but water blo in. He rolls it back up and the smudging gets worse. The truck shimmies from left to right, pushed by the wind THUNDER STRIKE rattles. Suddenly, THE SHAPE OF A PERSON STANDING IN THE ROAD.

dialogues.speaker: SHIT
dialogues.text: Curtis stomps on the brakes and turns the wheel. The truc hydroplanes. CRASH! Curtis' head busts against the steering column. Th front windshield cracks as the truck jerks to a stop. The HISS of a broken radiator. Curtis winces from the blo to his head. Hannah is crying. He reaches over to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay? Hannah physically looks all right, but she continues cryi Curtis reaches out and places a hand on her head. He's dazed, mumbling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're okay. The truck is angled up slightly like the front end has in up a pole. A cut on his forehead has begun to bleed. He sees movement. A PERSON passes by the hazy side window A SHAPE moves past the driver's window. The truck shifts as weight is added to the bed. The SOUND SOMEONE pulling things from the back of the truck. A mome WHACK! Curtis flinches as a 2X4 pounds the windshield. The truck jostles from the weight of someone jumping on t hood. Bump. Bump. The roof caves in with two FOOTSTEPS. Curtis looks around frantically. He reaches over to Hanna and begins to unstrap her from the car seat. 18.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SMASH! A BOARD breaks through the Passenger Window. A WOMAN, pale and aggressive, stands in the rain storm staring through the broken glass. She reaches for the loc Curtis pulls Hannah from the child seat and recoils again his door but is jolted as another board CRASHES through t driver's window. A HAND yanks Curtis by his collar. He's pulled against th door. A pasty forearm wraps around his neck, choking him. He strains against the arm. Sucks air. Needing to breath. The Woman at the passenger door grabs for Hannah. Curtis kicks at her. A MAN's boot KICKS OUT the back window. The Man in the be of the truck reaches for Curtis' face. He flails and kick unable to break free from the forearm at his door. The Woman gets hold of Hannah. The child is yanked from Curtis' arms. He screams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah! Hannah! Hands claw at Curtis' face. Scratching. Blood streaks. Th Woman has disappeared into the storm with Hannah. Curtis screams. Fingers swoop into his open mouth, grabbi hold of his cheek. They pull the cheek back. TEARING. He yells in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samantha walks down the hallway holding Hannah's shoes. Hannah trails behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here honey. Put on your shoes

dialogues.speaker: IN THE KITCHEN,
dialogues.text: Samantha walks in. Curtis is standing at the counter in h undershirt and boxers pouring a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, you're up. Curtis doesn't turn to greet her. He just stirs a spoon i the black coffee. Samantha walks up to him and puts a hand on his back. She notices that his shirt is soaked with sweat. 19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, you're soaked. He turns, taking a sip from the mug. She feels his forehe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've felt better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess we could stay home if we need to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you goin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Saturday, I was going to take Hannah to my booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Yeah. Curtis walks to the table and takes a seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look really sick honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm all right. It's just a cold or somethin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me get you some Advil. She heads for the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Don't worry about it. Ya'll just go. I'll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. (holds up the mug) Better already. Samantha walks to her purse on the counter and roots thro to find a set of keys. 20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. I got my phone if you need anything. Don't forget Sunday lunch is here tomorrow. This reminder makes Curtis rub his face with a grunt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're sick, we should cancel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, we'll talk later. She heads for the door with Hannah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Samantha scoops up her bag and takes Hannah by the hand. leave the room. Curtis notices the dog, Red, sitting on his haunches look at him. Curtis stares back, sipping his coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The reverse lights shine as Curtis' pick-up rumbles backw Curtis eyes the side mirror as he maneuvers the truck int his backyard. In the mirror, the trash pile comes into vi Just behind it, the STORM SHELTER doors appear. The truck shutters to a stop. Curtis studies the Shelter the side mirror for a moment. A grassy bulge with angled metal doors peeking over the trash heap. He climbs out. A blue tarp is pulled from the bed of the truck, floating down to the yard. Curtis slips on a pair of work gloves and continues to ey the Storm Shelter. He yanks a bale of chain-link from the bed of the truck and carries it to the back corner of the yard. He steals another glance back toward the Shelter. 21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dropping the bale, he sizes up the space. He looks to the sky. It's a beautiful day. He begins counting off steps from the back fence line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -A linen sheet floats down over a folding table. -The hanging bag is placed on a portable clothes rod. -Hands place an assortment of home sewn crafts like napki and embroidered pillows out onto the table. -A tackle box is opened revealing a tray of small bills a change. A calculator is removed. Hannah kneels in front of a folding chair behind their BO at an open-air flea market. She uses the seat of the chai as a table for a tiny porcelain tea set. Samantha stands over her display table smiling and noddin perusing CUSTOMERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -A mallet drives tall metal stakes into the ground. -The cord holding together the bale of chain-link is snip and a boot rolls the fencing out flat. -Chain-link is attached to the stakes with a number of me braids. -The prefab DOGHOUSE is set down in the back corner. Curtis stands in front of his newly created dog pen. It's waist high and about 7' X 10', tucked in the back left co of the yard so that half of the pen is made up by the existing fencing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samantha turns to see a large woman holding up an intrica embroidered pillow. You can tell by the look of her that she's a flea market a BARGAIN HUNTER(54).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much you asking for this pillow? 22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This pillow's fifteen dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's more than I want to spend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is all hand stitched. It takes a really long time. That's why I charge that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give you seven for it. Samantha looks at the woman, who is almost daring her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't go that low.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well that's my offer. The woman sets down the pillow and begins looking over ot items on the table. Samantha bites the inside of her chee She doesn't like to haggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about 10? The woman doesn't look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give you eight, but it's in change. Samantha forces a smile and motions to Hannah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fine. The woman smiles and removes a Ziplock bag of assorted co from her purse. Hannah takes the bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky for you she likes to count change. Hannah opens the bag and begins to turn it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis unlatches a piece of the braided wire holding a separated section of fencing that acts like a gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red! Come on. 23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens it and looks down at Red, who sits at his feet. speaks gently to the dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get in. Red walks into the pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good boy. Curtis closes the gate, kneels and places his hands on th fence. Red approaches so that his nose is touching Curtis fingers. Curtis scratches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about this buddy. We just gotta work it like this for awhile okay? Curtis stands, wiping his hands off on his jeans. He sees the Storm Shelter poking up from behind the trash pile. H looks down at Red. Curtis walks to the Shelter. Clearing past the trash pile the shelter appears, the mound fully visible. Curtis stops at the angled doors. He studies them. A rust padlock is snapped shut across the handles. He reaches ou and lifts up the padlock. He yanks on it, then lets it fa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coins splash across the kitchen counter. Curtis sets an empty coffee can back on the shelf in front of him and be sifting through the change. Odd screws, buttons, then he gets to what he's looking fo A small set of brass keys on a matching ring. He grabs th keys from the pile and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis walks back out to the storm shelter, keys in hand, long flashlight in his back pocket. He pulls up the padlock that holds the two rusted doors together. Popping off the rubber cover, he tries a key. T lock pops up. He unhooks it from the doors and lets it fa to the ground. Curtis strains to pull the first door open. It's heavy an sticks from lack of use. Finally, with a creak, the door swings back. 24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis holds his head to the side, a musty odor coming fr inside. He forces the second door open. Curtis stands in front of the shelter, a gaping black hol angled up from the earth. He takes the flashlight from his pocket and turns it on. illuminates concrete steps leading down. The dog, nose at the fence, watches from his pen on the o side of the yard. Curtis enters the shelter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's pitch black inside. Curtis makes his way down the st and holds out the flashlight. An assortment of trash on t ground, empty cans and water bottles, some candy wrappers The whole shelter is only about 6' X 8'. His head fits fi but he still ducks like he might bump it. He shines the light on the back wall. A rotted, wooden be is bolted into the concrete there. Curtis walks to it and takes a seat. He's looking back toward the steps now. A shaft of light cuts a strict beam through the open doors, lighting only concrete entry. Curtis takes in the quiet of the concrete box. He leans h head back on the wall and closes his eyes. He shuts off his flashlight. Left in the dark, he takes a deep breath. Exhales slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While rescue workers made several attempts to reach the family, Walter Jacobs wife... Curtis sits in his Lazyboy bent over a frozen dinner. He watches the local news on TV. Samantha walks in with a gl of milk and some Oreos, a magazine tucked under her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samantha takes a TIN down from the top of the fridge. It designs of starfish and other ocean creatures on it. 25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sets the tin on the counter next to the tackle box sh uses as a cash register and yells to Curtis in the den.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's what I don't understand. If he didn't do anything why did you put him out back? Samantha counts out the money earned at the flea market. sets a portion aside and closes the tackle box. Curtis sa something, but it's inaudible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? She opens the tin and removes an envelope with the word "BEACH" written on it in black sharpie. Samantha adds the money to the envelope and puts up the jar. She opens the fridge and takes out the milk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hear me? I said if he didn't do anything why did you have to put him outside? Curtis' attention is on the TV. Samantha sits on the couc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted him to be outside for awhile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's your dog. He's always been an inside dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's my dog, and that's why he's outside. Right now with Hannah and everything I just think it'd be better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah loves Red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on. Curtis stares at the television program. Samantha's eyes narrow. Frustrated, she flips open her magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the gas cloud spread across their six acre property.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS ANCHOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The only way off their land was across the train tracks which were blocked by wreckage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from a hospital bed) I tried using some wet rags and towels to breathe through but that just seemed to make it worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While rescue workers made several attempts to reach the family, Walter Jacobs' wife and brother-in- law died in the home. Jacobs survived despite enduring eleven hours of exposure to the gas cloud before finally being flown out by helicopter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hearin' this? Her nose still in the magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's awful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleven hours. No way out. Samantha shakes her head. Curtis watches the footage of Walter Jacobs. He watches his red rimmed eyes. The deep lines in his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's daytime, but the house feels dark from the storm blo outside. The SOUND of rain pelts the windows and roof. Curtis, dressed for work, walks from his bedroom down the hallway. He passes the den and stops at its entryway.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE DEN,
dialogues.text: Hannah sits on the couch with her back to him. She's on h knees looking out one of the front windows. A dull orange glow halos from the bank of windows. What sunlight there is appears diffused by the dark, thick rai smearing down the outside of the glass. A THUNDER STRIKE. 27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis flinches. He shows concern as heavier rain begins battering the house. The wind picks up making wood beams creak on their foundation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah. Hannah doesn't move. She continues staring out the window The SOUND of the storm outside intensifies. Windows begin rattle in their frames. Curtis walks over and reaches for Hannah but is startled the sight of a MAN'S FACE just outside the window. Hannah and the Man have been staring at one another. The Man, hollow eyed and pale, moves out of the window an out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Thunder CRACKS overhead. Curtis scoops Hannah into his ar and heads out of the room. BANG. The front door rattles. Curtis stops and turns back BANG. BANG. The SOUND of someone kicking at the front doo The storm outside has grown to a deafening pitch. The power goes out. The entire house vibrates, like a freight train running across the roof. The BANGING at the front door continues, frame giving way, as the STORM reaches its apex. Curtis, holding Hannah, kneels and braces himself in the entryway to the den. He covers the back of Hannah's head with his hands and squeezes her tight into his shoulder. Then Silence. A stillness. The rain stops. No more banging at the front door. The SU moves brightly though the front windows. WOOSH. The furniture in the den lifts off the ground. A couch, Lazyboy, coffee table and lamp. It all hangs in the air, floating for a moment. Quietly. Curtis watches, eyes wide. A rumbling. Grows. The SUNLIGH vanishes. SMASH! The sound of the storm is sucked back into the roo the furniture crashes to the floor, breaking apart on imp 28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The windows BLOW OUT. Curtis squeezes his eyes shut and pivots his body, trying protect Hannah. Shards of glass splinter across his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis gasps for air. It doesn't come. Gasp. He's sucking for a breath. Hyperventilating. He rises up in bed, gasping. His face flushed and head soaked in sweat. His eyes dart around the room, frantical searching his surroundings. One more gasp, and air enters his lungs. He coughs. More air. Long, deep breaths. He's calming down. His breathing comes under control. His attention turns to something else. Something under the sheets. Curtis pulls back the bed sheets. The mattress is soaked YELLOW urine. This scares him. His hand trembles as he reaches out to touch his wet boxe The toilet FLUSHES. Footsteps in heels. Curtis quickly pulls the covers back up. Samantha enters bedroom. She pulls her hair into a tight ponytail and pic earrings off a nearby dresser, her back to Curtis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got the number for Dr. Shannan? She turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're still not feeling good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but you got the number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, yeah baby but he'll be closed today. She approaches the bed and he holds his hand out. 29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Yeah. I'll call tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey if you're not feeling good we take you in somewhere. She walks closer to the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Stop! She's taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Do you want me to cancel lunch today...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I'm sorry. It's just I got a sore throat. I'm sorry I'm taking it out on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was gonna leave Hannah with you so I could go to church, but I'm not going to with you like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fine. I'll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. She needs breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry that you feel bad but you need to drop the attitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. Just go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I'm sorry. Just go. 30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah's in the den. We have cereal for her. Samantha stomps out of the room. Curtis sighs. He halfway lifts the sheet then lets it fall again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis strips the sheets off the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The laundry room is a stackable set squeezed into a close off the hallway. Curtis loads the sheets into the washer and presses start Watching the clothes spin, a thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis pushes Hannah's shoe onto her foot. He stops with shoes to concentrate. He moves his index finger from one shoulder to the other and speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going out. Confused, she slices her finger down an open palm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with open palms) We're going out. Okay? It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis leads Hannah up the front walk of the Grafton Publ Library. It's a one-story brick building with 1960's architecture. The parking lot is nearly empty behind them

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis holds the glass front door open for Hannah. They s in the entryway and survey the LIBRARY. There are only a few people, one of which is the LIBRARIA sitting behind a central desk. It is an open room with cinder block walls painted in brightly colored shapes. 31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis finds the children's section to the left and leads Hannah over. She takes a seat at a kid's size table as Curtis grabs a Dinosaur book from a nearby display. Kneeling in front of her, Curtis shows her the book and motions with open hands to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stay put okay? Hannah begins looking through the book. Curtis stands, he sees a set of computers under a sign reading, "CATALOGUE"

dialogues.speaker: AT THE COMPUTERS,
dialogues.text: Curtis takes a seat in front of one of the two computers up on a folding table. He eyes the search screen. Title, Author, Subject. He clicks on "Subject" and types the word "DREAMS". He scrolls through a list of titles and writes down a number He looks back for Hannah. She's still flipping through he book. No one else is around. He begins another search. He types "MENTAL ILLNESS".

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BOOK SHELVES,
dialogues.text: Curtis scans the spines looking for his title. He already holds two books against his chest. He pulls out a thick hard cover book. The title reads, "Understanding Mental Illness."

dialogues.speaker: I/E. CURTIS' TRUCK/GRAFTON STREETS
dialogues.text: Hannah is once again strapped into her car seat. She hold big children's book in her hands. They pass a Grocery Store. Curtis turns as it goes by. The truck pulls a U-turn in the street and heads for the store parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis pushes a cart down the aisle. Hannah rides in the fold down metal seat. They stop at the bottled water section. Curtis loads seve plastic, gallon jugs of water into his cart. The cart is filled with an assortment of supplies: Batteries, canned food, first aid supplies, matches. 32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samantha sits in the dining room at a fully dressed table Steam rises off bowls of mashed potatoes and green beans. Fried chicken piled on a platter. MELVIN(58) taps his finger on the empty plate in front of and subtly checks his watch. JANINE(57) smooths out the embroidered table cloth. KATHRYN(37) and CHARLIE(39) tend to their child, REX(3). repeatedly jams a finger into the potatoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's just start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's all join hands for the blessing. The SOUND of the front door opening. Samantha gets up and leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: BY THE FRONT DOOR,
dialogues.text: Curtis has Hannah in his arms. He closes the door. Samant appears behind them. She speaks in a hushed, angry voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the hell have you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I'm sorry. I had to run an errand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're really late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't even bring your cell phone. Samantha heads back to the dining room. Curtis sucks his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Potatoes dalloped, chicken passed, the table is active wi the family serving and eating. Curtis watches it all, somehow separated from it. He's exhausted. 33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Missed you at church this mornin' Curtis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows what to do if he wants me to stop askin'. Curtis looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it a good service?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was. It was good work. Curtis nods. The family in front of him eats the meal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm thinking about cleaning up that storm shelter out back. They look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light from the open closet door cuts a shape in the relatively dark hallway. Curtis roots through the back of the closet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -Curtis sweeps the concrete floor of the storm shelter. A Coleman camping lantern sits on the wooden bench attached the back wall. It casts an odd light up into the room. -Curtis places cans of food onto metal shelves. -Curtis flips through keys on his key ring. He adds the t small padlock keys to the ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samantha sits on the bed in her pajamas applying lotion t her legs. She wipes the remainder on her knuckles and loo at the empty spot on Curtis' side of the bed. 34.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samantha walks into the kitchen and turns off the overhea light. She pauses, seeing something in the backyard. She stops at the back door and stares out at the storm shelter. The camp lantern's orange light glows through th open metal doors. She watches for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shelter has been cleaned up. The metal shelves hold canned food, water jugs and first aid supplies. Blankets pillows are stacked on the other side of the room. Curtis sits in the back corner of the shelter on the wood bench. He flips through one of the books from the library The cover reads, "DREAM ANALYSIS AND INTERPRETATION". The book on mental illness sits by his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Doctor's Office is a converted one-story residential house. Curtis slouches in a faux leather chair grouped in the small reception area. He has nodded off. His head snaps up. He sucks air through his nose and sits in his chair. He sees a WOMAN(25) reading a children's bo aloud to her DAUGHTER(3) on a colorful rug in the corner. A door opens and a NURSE with a clipboard steps out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis? Curtis stands and follows the nurse out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis sits, fully clothed, on the edge of a paper covere bench in the exam room. DOCTOR SHANNAN, an older man with smoker's voice, enters smiling and gives a firm handshake

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis, how you doin' bud?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's my girl? 35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Doctor turns to a small table in the corner and grabs wooden tongue depressor and an otoscope from a drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good to hear. Tilt your head back for me. The Doctor shines the otoscope into his nostrils.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have a cold. The Doctor pauses and turns to check a chart on the table

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Did she get that down wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I just told her that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. So what's the problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been havin'...I've been having some trouble sleepin'. I was hopin' you could give me somethin' for it. Doctor Shannan takes a seat on a rolling stool and proces the request.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long's this been goin' on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `Bout four nights now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not sleepin' at all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well some, but real restless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I think four nights is a little too soon to tell. My advice would be to not eat or drink anything after 8 o'clock at night. Cut back on any alcoholic drinks, tobacco, caffeine...get some daily exercise. 36.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I think... Curtis isn't sure how much he wants to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I may need to try some medication.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you say that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The reason I've been having trouble sleeping is because of some dreams I've been havin'. I didn't think it was anything at first, but then the other day I woke up and the bed was wet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You urinated in your bed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Couple days before that I had a dream that my dog attacked me and it took all day for the pain in my arm to go away. Doctor Shannan leans his back against the table and think about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You been to see your mother lately? He swivels the stool around and writes on a prescription

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been about a month. He tears two sheets off and holds the first out to Curtis

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. This is a prescription for a pretty mild sedative. It's non- habit forming, but I'm only giving you enough for a few days anyway. Take it and see if it helps. In the meantime, (holds up the other slip) This is the number of a good friend of mine in Columbus. He's a psychiatrist. It's a drive, but he's the best I know. 37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give him a call and let him know you'll be down to see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The construction site sits in the middle of open farmland is considerably more involved than Curtis' last job site. Dump trucks, backhoes and cement mixers roll and beep acr muddy ground. A 20 MAN CREW operates throughout.

dialogues.speaker: NEAR THE WELL DRILLING RIG,
dialogues.text: Dewart pushes down a lever that activates the hydraulic l for the drill. Curtis appears behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Dewart!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you say Curtis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much. Curtis kneels at the ground beside the rig. Sifts dirt through his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They want us to get a pilot hole drilled by lunch. I figure worse comes to worse we can eat on the rig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we'll get it done. Weekend all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Same old shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's lunchtime. The men sit around in different groups eating out of bagged lunches. Curtis eats a sandwich and watches the men. Some bitching Others laughing. 38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wind blows through a wooded area nearby. He watches the leaves move. He looks to the sky. It's a beautiful day. Almost peaceful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The insurance office sits in a row of small downtown buildings.

dialogues.speaker: INSURANCE AGENT, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: No. I need the name of the specialist whose diagnosis you'll accept.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An INSURANCE AGENT(62) sits behind her desk with the phon her ear. She's an older woman wearing a pant suit. Samantha sits by a fake plant and sips a Coke. She watche Hannah play with building blocks from a plastic tub provi by the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into the phone) No. Look it. I've told you this twice. Please. Just get me the name and or the approval code.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. The Agent writes something down.

dialogues.speaker: INSURANCE AGENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into the phone) All right. And the phone. Well great. Thank you very much. The Agent hangs up the phone and rips a piece of paper fr the pad in front of her. She hands it to Samantha.

dialogues.speaker: INSURANCE AGENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is the name and number of the specialist who the insurance company approves of. Just call and make an appointment. Now if this doctor signs off , you should have the implant procedure fully covered. I'm sorry it took so long. Samantha looks at the paper, impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I give you a hug? 39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fine. It's fine. You know your husband's company actually has very good insurance when it kicks in. Not a lot of jobs offer policies half as good. You're very lucky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis stands in line at the pharmacy located in the back corner of the grocery store. He approaches the counter an hands over his prescription to a female PHARMACIST. She disappears behind a divider as Curtis removes his wal He takes out an insurance card and runs his thumb over th bills. The Pharmacist returns with a stapled white bag. Curtis holds out the insurance card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay. We have your insurance on file. That'll be $47.64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the co-pay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is your co-pay. Curtis studies the small paper sack and removes three, 20 dollar bills from his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis enters the front door, closing it behind him. He turns and is met by Samantha, who wraps her arms around h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. She squeezes him. Then kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have good news. 40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis finishes off a dinner of roast and potatoes. Saman sets the piece of paper the Insurance Agent gave her in f of him and begins clearing the table. Hannah draws on a piece of construction paper at the othe end of the table. Samantha picks up a crayon and shows it Hannah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Green? How `bout a red? She pretends to use the crayon as lipstick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was like talking to a sane person for once. She made one phone call. That's it. I've been trying that 800 number for weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's great. It's great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Hannah. Hannah doesn't look up. He stands and goes over to her. Touches her shoulder and kneels beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You excited? Huh? We're gonna get you some help. Curtis touches his finger to her chest then stops. He can think of the sign. He turns to Samantha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you say...sign excited?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like this. Samantha shows him the sign. Curtis mimics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excited. Yeah? Hannah nods. He kisses her on the forehead. He picks up a crayon and holds it up to her lips like lipstick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I got to do you. 41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samantha lies under the covers looking at a real estate magazine. Curtis takes off his clothes by the dresser. He subtly removes a prescription bottle from his pants pocke and cups it in his palm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, honey. Look at this one. It's a 2-1 and it sits directly on the beach. Wouldn't that be great? We wouldn't have to worry about Hannah crossing traffic. Curtis walks over and leans in to see the page. They are rental photos of beach condos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the rent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight ninety nine a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sounds real nice. Samantha keeps flipping through the magazine as Curtis he to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis turns the water on in the sink and shakes two pill from the orange bottle. He stuffs them in his mouth and chases it with water from the faucet. Curtis looks at himself in the mirror for a moment before cutting out the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crack in the ceiling slowly comes into focus. Curtis sits up in bed, rubbing his eyes. He looks around room. He hears Samantha in the kitchen. He takes a deep breath, smelling the breakfast cooking. Curtis smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis sits at the kitchen table as Samantha dishes up so eggs. 42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sleep well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look like you're feeling better. Curtis nods and eats his breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis and Dewart attach a drill bit to the rig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to come there and do it for you? Jesus. Curtis steadies the large metal piece as Dewart ratchets down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, how much food do you think you'd need to live on for a week?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean to stay alive. What do you think you'd need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. You hear about people livin' for days all the time offa bark and melted snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never heard of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit I don't know. You asked the question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's on there. It's on. Come on. 43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis steps back from the arm of the drill. Dewart taps wrench on two bolts to make sure they are secure. A LOUD BOOM RATTLES. THUNDER. Curtis flinches at the sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Curtis turns around and checks the sky. It's clear blue. Not a cloud in sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sounds like thunder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What sounds like thunder? BOOM. ANOTHER THUNDER STRIKE. Curtis doesn't move. He watches Dewart walk to the contro of the drilling rig. MORE THUNDER. ROLLING NOW. Curtis steps back from the rig and checks the horizons. Nothing. It's a beautiful day. Dewart looks down at him. Curtis' face is pale, scared. Curtis looks at him. Not sure what to say. Curtis turns a walks to his truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you goin'? Curtis. Where you goin'?

dialogues.speaker: BY CURTIS' TRUCK,
dialogues.text: Curtis stops and rests his hands on the bed of the truck. Another THUNDER STRIKE makes him flinch. Curtis VOMITS next to the back tire. He quickly stands, wiping his mouth. He checks over his shoulders to see if anyone has seen him.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. CURTIS' TRUCK/RURAL HIGHWAY
dialogues.text: Curtis studies his face in the rearview mirror as he sail down the rural highway. 44.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rubs his eyes with the back of his hand and looks in t side mirror. The horizon is still clear. Curtis begins to hyperventilate. Short breaths accompanie by cold sweat. Sucking air. He can't breath. He panics. The truck tires slide on the gravel shoulder as he abrupt slams on the brakes and steers off the highway. Dust settles outside as Curtis begins to get his breathin under control. He rests his head on the steering wheel an shuts his eyes tight. Everything quiets down. His breathing. The road. No more thunder. Curtis looks out his passenger window. His truck has stopped in front of a Tractor Trailer Depot rusted shipping container with giant white letters painte it reads, "CONTAINERS FOR SALE". Curtis stares at this. He climbs out of the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis walks around his truck to get a better look at the depot. The dirt lot is piled high with containers. He studies the "FOR SALE" sign, then a smaller sign next it that lists available sizes. Curtis turns back to his truck and rubs his face, still shaking things off. He looks up at the sky. Clear and blu A thought comes to him. He checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. CURTIS' TRUCK/INTERSTATE
dialogues.text: Curtis drives down a divided four-lane interstate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis' truck pulls into the parking lot of the Pleasant Grove Apartments. It's a well manicured, new construction facility. The words "AN ASSISTED LIVING COMMUNITY" are written under the apartment name on the sign out front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis stands by the door for apartment 212 in an interio carpeted hallway. He knocks. 45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A passing ATTENDANT guides an elderly WOMAN down the hall Curtis nods to them. The door opens. SARAH(61), a plainly dressed woman much t young to live in a nursing home, looks surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Mom. Her eyes light up and she wraps her arms around Curtis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. She leads him inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The apartment is small, but nicely kept. Not much furnitu or personal trappings. Framed family photos mostly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to get some water. He fills his glass at the sink. Takes a sip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want some?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis enters the living area as Sarah stops in the kitchenette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah runs her fingers around the bent edges of a small p of Hannah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't she lovely. Curtis drops his head. He looks uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom? 46.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to ask you somethin'. She looks at him. Totally open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you remember what year we brought you up here? To the first place. She has to think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was `86.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Because Kyle was going to be a senior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was 10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Curtis nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you remember what happened before you got diagnosed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean...I just want to know how it all started. Before you had to leave. Sarah settles in her chair, understanding the question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know. I remember it was a real stressful time. Your father was gone a lot, and I couldn't handle things on my own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ever have any dreams? Like bad dreams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Nothing like that. There was always...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (searches for the words) There was always a panic that took hold of me. I thought people were watching me or listening to me. I... Sarah is remembering. Her face draws tight, frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right. It's all right. It's fine. Sarah looks up and smiles. Her focus shifts back to her s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Yeah. I'm fine. Sarah looks back down to Hannah's photo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The relatively new gas station sits just off the intersta Curtis stands at the pump filling up his truck. He watches the numbers next to the dollar sign roll highe He looks back at the busy freeway. Cars passing. The pump stops. The final amount reads, "$68.79". He hang the hose back onto the pump and pulls a cell phone from h pocket. He dials and waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into the phone) May I have the number for Doctor George Shannan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. Curtis, phone still at his ear, turns and watches the horizon. The sun hangs low in the sky. A reddish haze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into the phone) Hi, is Doctor Shannan there? May I speak with him? This is Curtis LaForche.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Doc. Yeah, sorry...Sorry to call you at home, I just don't think I can make it to Columbus to see that psychiatrist. Yeah, it's just too far. Is there somewhere local you can send me? 48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis steps quietly into the bedroom. The lights are on, but Samantha has fallen asleep on top of the made bed. He empties his pockets on the dresser and Samantha wakes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hey. Sorry I woke you up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay. Where you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went to see mom. Samantha sits up in the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm hmm. I just wanted to check up on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shoulda told me we would have gone with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay. Samantha lays back down, tucking herself under the covers

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will in a bit. Curtis finishes emptying his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah sleeps soundly in her bed. Curtis stands at the do watching her. He walks over and takes a seat on the edge the bed. He listens to her breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The backyard is almost pitch black. Curtis stands in fron of the storm shelter doors holding out the Coleman Lanter 49.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He surveys the backyard with it. The trash pile has been removed leaving the yard more open. Curtis begins to count steps out from the left edge of th shelter doors. He counts to himself, three feet per strid He begins to outline a rectangle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is quiet and the den is lit by a single lamp. Curtis sits alone on the couch, hunched over the coffee table. He writes on a yellow legal pad. It's a list with the heading, "REMODEL". It reads: -Shipping Container, $1,800

dialogues.speaker: -PVC,
dialogues.text: -Plumbing and waste, $1,650 -Bobcat, $1,750 -Jackhammer with pneumatics, $800 -Sealant, $150 -Dirt, -$250 At the bottom of the list, Curtis writes the figure, "$7, and circles it. He studies the number, then begins drawing a rectangular diagram below it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis blows into a Styrofoam cup and stares through the blinds of an office window. Outside, a flag snaps at the of a pole next to the FIRST NATIONAL BANK sign. He looks down at a NEWSPAPER laid out on an end table nex him. He flips it over and studies the ads on the back. A big one in the corner catches his eye. It reads, "CUYAHOGA GUN AND KNIFE SHOW!" The ad lists ite for sell/trade: ...Tactical Gear, Gas Masks, Batons... Curtis focuses in on the words "Gas Masks" and tears the out. JOHN MYERS(34) enters with a set of papers in his ha Curtis quickly tucks the ad into his back pocket. Myers takes a seat in one of two chairs in front of his d and looks over the papers. He takes a pen out of his pock as Curtis sits down next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well you've kept up with the payments on the house. 50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been good about that. Myers nods, but he carries a look of concern. He confides

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta tell you Curtis, banks aren't loaning money the way they used to. We've got you a loan today, but the interest rates are variable and we have to tie it to your house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fine. Myers sits back, drawing the pen to his lips and tapping

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis, I've known you a long time. We financed your house for you, two vehicles. I'm telling you this is a risky loan you're taking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need the money John. Myers nods, then leans forward and clicks the pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis opens the door to his truck which is parked in the bank's lot. He unbuttons his starched white shirt and pla it on the truck seat. He pulls out a dirty blue work shirt and begins buttoning

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dewart sits at the controls of the drilling rig. He sees Curtis approaching through the construction site. Curtis waves two fingers at him. Dewart shuts down the drill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry I left you yesterday. 51.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dewart hops down and the two approach the drill site. Dew seems sullen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim came by. I covered for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need your help with the depth charts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis and Dewart sit on the drilling rig eating lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuckin' Nat put me in charge of frying oysters for that Lions Club supper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need another burner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, if you still got yours I could use it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think you could help me with somethin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatta you need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna build out the tornado shelter in my backyard. I could use some help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hell you wanna do that for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just needs to be done. Dewart eyes him, unsure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you need? 52.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figure I'll do it on Saturday, borrow some equipment from work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just need a backhoe, a hauler. I'll rent the rest. Dewart stares off into the distance. He notices Curtis looking at him, waiting for an answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Whatever. I'll help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all right man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just don't wanna see you fuck up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis stands and talks with a MAN in the middle of the Tractor Trailer Depot just off the highway. The Man point to a row of shipping containers and uses his hands to mim how one would be lowered. They shake hands and Curtis walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Community Health Center is a one-level, aged brick building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis sits in the lobby filling out a clipboard full of forms and questionnaires. Light traffic flows in and out. He flips a page over. The section heading reads, "Family Medical History". Curtis begins to write. 53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis references a slip of paper as he looks for a room number in a long, linoleum tiled hallway; a book and note tucked under his arm. He finds the correct door ajar and knocks.

dialogues.speaker: KENDRA, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KENDRA(42), a black woman with short hair, sits behind a public issue desk in a public issue office. A poster abou flu shots hangs on the wall. There is no personal decor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. She half stands and offers a hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a seat. I'm Kendra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis. Curtis shakes and they sit. Kendra opens a manila folder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna start by askin' you some questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. I already answered all the questions on the forms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know. I looked at `em, but I need to get a profile started on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Well... Curtis slides the yellow legal pad out of the book he brought. It's the library book on Mental Illness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of the five possible symptoms needed to be diagnosed with

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reads off the pad) delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, disorganized behavior, and the negative symptoms, I've had two. Delusions and hallucinations. But they say it has to continue for six months to be diagnosed schizophrenia and mine hasn't been goin' on anywhere near that long.
